description:
Plex is like running your own personal Netflix server. The only thing that would make it better, since it's already free of charge, would be if it was open source. It runs on your server and gives a user friendly interface for interacting with it via a web browser, mobile apps on your phone, etc. Re-encoding is done by the server, so if you want to stream something on your phone over a cellular data connection, you can set it to a lower quality and the server re-encodes the stream in real time. This means your cell phone doesn't have to do any of the heavy lifting.

It lets you add a variety of media library types (Movies, TV Shows), automatically matches entries and pulls the metadata for them, supports embedded subtitles, etc. If somebody tries to play something in a format that device doesn't support, it re-encodes it in real time to a format that it does support.

It authenticates with plex.tv, but once you have a server set up, you can invite others to browse your Plex server and share your libraries with them. That also means that you don't have to manage the user accounts of people you want to share your server with, the Plex website basically acts as an authentication gateway for your server. You can create accounts for your children and then set parental controls on those accounts so that they do not see any content you don't want them to see.

The snap version means that it's contained, includes everything necessary, and can automatically keep itself up to date, so no more adding yet another third party repository or manually downloading and installing the new deb files whenever updates come out.
Feels very first class, and got it working out of the box with minimal configuration and pointing to a SMB music share. Great work!

I had Plex running on my Ubuntu server via the manual Linux distro... at the time the Ubuntu Software (app store) didnt have Plex. It was always a few more steps to update manually via the distro-method, so I did have to uninstall the old server and recreate with the Ubuntu App store method, but I'm fine with that. Just for the ease of updates. I'm a Plex Pass lifer but I dont use the beta builds - so again, just for ease of updates - I was fine with the re-install. Love Plex and love Ubuntu!
summary: Had to remove/re-install over previous Plex..

description: Helped me defeat the Cylons!

Actually using the FreeNAS plugin version, Plex is 5 star software, it is the thing we have all been searching for since the 1980's when we got a collection of VHS, since the 1990's when we wanted to use xBox to watch movies on TV and, since BT when we learned we wanted to stream our content anywhere. This will do it all.
incredible fun and useful
When I uninstalled the downloaded .deb, and installed the Snap instead, it simply won't work -- new created server is "Unclaimed" and the "Claim" button silently fails.
summary: Plex is great, but Snap version didn't work

description:
...but don't install it from here. Install it manually using the DEB files. I realize this is more difficult, but I've had some issues with the one from the Ubuntu Software app. Specifically it lost my entire library, which isn't a big deal -- the media files were still there -- but I had to re-categorize my files and fix the problematic matches.

Additionally, if you did already install Plex here and you then install Plex from the DEB file, you will have two Plex Media Servers in a race condition!

That being said, once you have your Plex Media Server installed and configured the way you want, you will probably want to buy the lifetime Plex membership. This gives you remote access from anywhere, an SSL cert for your Plex server, and a bunch of other goodies. Worth it and a good way to support the Plex developers.
summary: The best media server by far

description: https://www.plex.tv

I have installed Plex on various linux systems over the years and it always takes a little work. Instead of setting up the Plex repository I used the snap and it worked out of the box. Permissions for folders in home directory worked. Good job!

Had 2 instances installed. Then uninstalled the version that wasn't from the app store and this one then wouldn't work. Manually started the service and it still doens't work. Very poor experience, it should have done an in-place upgrade/update.
summary: Horrible experience if you have the server installed already

description:
The best at what it does, but only due to lack of competition.

It does, what it say's but not without frustration and some pretty startlingly bad design decisions.

I'd try Emby before you resort to this.
summary: Don't know what I could recommend in it's place but frustrating af

description: Unable to run the app
Mved to Ubuntu as my main OS recently and it's been a seamless transition with PLex. Happy.

I have plex running as a snap on my ubuntu server. Occaisionally crashes, and I can no longer get updates from the snap store.

Otherwise a good program. Organizes your media and allows you to stream to chromecast, which is exactly what I want it for.
one of the best experience ever had with a peace of software, fully in love!
summary: I love Plex so much that they deserved my plex pass!

description: Waste of time. Paywall.

Couldn't ask for anything better that iCan think of..... The Free use of it so far has me convinced that I'll pay for the App so to Record and Save some Antenna Air Digital TV footage from the Roku TVs.....
summary: Always Works Flawless whether iBoot in Windows or UBUNTU and ROKU TVs

description:

Love it!
